user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimedWrite:
```c
int32 OS_TimedWrite(osal_id_t filedes, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(nbytes);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericWrite_Impl(&token, buffer, nbytes, timeout);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimedWrite:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_GenericWrite_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    ssize_t                         os_result;
    uint32                          operation;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    if (nbytes > 0)
    {
        operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;

        /*
         * If filehandle is set with O_NONBLOCK, then must call select() here.
         *
         * The "selectable" field should be set false for those file handles
         * which the underlying OS does not support select() on.
         *
         * Note that a timeout will not work unless selectable is true.
         */
        if (impl->selectable)
        {
            return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(token, &operation, timeout);
        }

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && (operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE) != 0)
        {
            /* on some system libraries for which the write() argument is not
             * qualified correctly, it needs to be case to a void* here */
            os_result = write(impl->fd, GENERIC_IO_CONST_DATA_CAST buffer, nbytes);
            if (os_result < 0)
            {
                OS_DEBUG("write: %s\n", strerror(errno));
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                /* type conversion from ssize_t to int32 for return */
                return_code = (int32)os_result;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only potential unreachable-code issue visible in the provided snippets is the relation between the caller-side size check and the callee-side conditional: OS_TimedWrite invokes OS_CHECK_SIZE(nbytes) which enforces nbytes > 0; the callee OS_GenericWrite_Impl then has an outer guard if (nbytes > 0) { ... }. For calls coming from OS_TimedWrite this makes the nbytes==0 path of that guard unreachable and should be investigated for Rule 2.1 compliance. No other obvious unreachable code fragments were found in the supplied code: all other conditional branches depend on function return values or runtime state (e.g. OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit return, impl->selectable, return_code checks) and are therefore potentially reachable; the pointer check macro (OS_CHECK_POINTER) performs input validation/error handling rather than introducing source-level dead code; assignments and release/transaction calls are on paths that can be exercised by error or success returns. If there are other call sites for OS_GenericWrite_Impl that do not enforce nbytes>0, those should be reviewed too, but such call sites were not provided.
